Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Developing a Controls Engineering Education Program for Input Shaping
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the field of controls engineering, command shaping techniques can be useful in a wide range of applications such as cranes, spacecraft, hard disk drives, and robotic arms. In particular, input shaping, which is a specific approach in command shaping, can be used to reduce vibration in flexible systems simply by altering the input command. Although input shaping has become increasingly prominent, quality educational programs for this control method are not readily available. This project will allow collaboration between Dr. Seong-Wook Hong, a recognized expert on input shaping, and the PI in the creation of new educational materials to expand the knowledge on this topic. Furthermore, the PI will leverage Dr. Hong's experimental equipment at the Kumoh National Institute of Technology in Korea to verify an input shaping method that will improve the controllability of ship-mounted boom cranes. This project will expand the knowledgebase of input shaping in complex dynamic systems while facilitating the education of future engineers on this topic.

Input shaping is a command shaping method by which a desired input command is convolved with a series of impulses to produce a shaped command that imparts little to no residual vibration. It is particularly useful in the control of cranes, which can exhibit multiple degrees of freedom. Because these systems tend to have an operator-in-the-loop, input shaping can offer better performance than a closed-loop feedback methods; its intuitive nature is more compatible with a human operator. The main drawback of this open-loop method is its inability to compensate for nonzero initial conditions. As part of this project, a new input shaping technique that eliminates such initial conditions will be experimentally tested. This research will facilitate the control of ship-mounted boom cranes, which are frequently used for such tasks as ASV retrieval and cargo transfer.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flexible robotic systems are widely used in industry due to their inherent advantages over rigid counterparts. While rigid systems must have more structural reinforcement to ensure flexibility does not occur, this increase in mass results in bulky, slow systems which are unsafe for operation alongside human operators. Furthermore, any mechanical system will exhibit some degree of flexibility when pushed to its performance limit. Therefore, as demand for higher productivity in various industrial sectors increases, a higher proportion of the robotic systems involved in production will be, by necessity, required to maintain precision in the presence of flexibility. For these reasons, it is imperative to continue advancing the state-of-the-art in the control systems which facilitate accurate, safe and efficient motion of flexible robotic systems.

This project focused on advancing the state-of-the-art for the control of flexible systems through a command shaping technique called input shaping. This tool has been used with consistent success in the control of various mechanical systems such as cranes, hard disk drives, and flexible manipulators. Input shaping creates a method for easily modifying an arbitrary reference command to aflexible system such that the resulting, shaped command results in minimal vibration at a minimal cost to the duration of the motion. 

In many cases, the flexible system may begin at a state that causes initial vibrations. As one example, an off-center crane payload will begin swinging when it is lifted off the ground. In cases such as this, a modified approach must be used to eliminate vibration. The work performed by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this project represents one approach to mitigate such vibration. If the initial states of the system are known, a modified input shaping approach can be used to eliminate the initial vibration. 

With the help of Professor Seong-Wook Hong at the Kumoh National Institute of Technology in Gumi, South Korea, the PI developed and experimentally tested mathematical models for such initial condition-canceling control methods. The equipment and expertise provided by Professor Hong proved to be invaluable assets in this research. 

As a result of this research and experimentation, one peer-reviewed journal article was published to the ASME Journal of Dynamic Systems, Measurement and Controls. Additionally, two conference publications were presented to peers in Seoul, Korea and Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Finally, this project opened opportunities for multiple undergraduate students from the Kumoh Instiute of Technology to visit the PI's university - The University of Louisiana at Lafayette - for a multi-week exchange program.
